page.title: 12LOWER HARDRES AREA-FARMS 3
page.content: Kings{New House Farm,}with 217 acres of top and soft fruit and cereal, is a family concern, now in the 4th genera- tion. The farm was one of the first to join the East Kent Packers Co-opera- tive. Adopting the North Holland method, tree branches are tied down to check unnecessary growth and yield more fruit. The "Pick your own" system is popular, customers often arriving as a coach party. The large 17th cen- tury farmhouse, supported entirely on beams, was declared an Historic Build- ing of Kent in the 1970's, and bears the red diamond-shaped plaque. In the scullery is a well 190 feet deep. An irrigation plant with 2400 gallon tank was installed in 1985. The two farm workers' houses built in 1890 stand beside the Bridleway which runs through the farm to Larkey Valley.
